case all through the country
of the Balonda so that
when we came to an
idol in the woods we
always knew that we
were within a quarter
of an hour of human
habitations - One idovery
ugly idol we passed had
two loops restinged on a
horizontal beam placed on
two upright posts - This
beam was furnished with
two loops of cord as of a
chain to suspend offerings
before it - On remarking
304
to our own my companions
that these idols had ears
but they heard not &c - I learned
that the ^ Balonda and Barotse even believe
that divination may be
43 performed by means of these
blocks of wood & clay
and though the wood itself
could not hear the owners
had medicines by which
they could be made to hear
and give responses,
so that if an enemy were
approaching they would
have full information
Manenko having brought
us to a stand on account
of slight indisposition and
desire to send forward
notice of our approach
to her uncle - I asked
if Shinte had idols who
could tell him everything
why it was necessary
to send forward information
of our movements - "She
did it only" was they reply -
It is seldom of much use
to shewshow one who worships
idols the folly of idolatry
without giving something
else instead - They do not love
them - They fear them and
betake themselves to their idols
only when in perplexity & danger

Chester Whilst delayed among the Balonda
villages a little to the South of
the town of Shinte by ManenkosManenko's
management we were well
44 supplied by the villagers
with sweet potatoes - and
green maize - SambanziaSambanza went
to his mothersmother's village for
supplies of other food and
as I was labouring under
fever I did not find it
difficult to exercise patience
with her whims - but it being
Saturday I thought we might
as well go on to the town
for Sunday (15th) "No, her
messenger must return
from her uncle first - " Being
sure that the answer of the
uncle would be favourable
we might I thought we might
go on at once and not
lose two days in the same
spot - "No it is out custom"
and everything else I could urge
was answered in the genuine
pertinaceouspertinacious lady style - She
ground some meal for me
with her own hands and
when she brought it told me
she had actually gone to a
village and begged corn for
the purpose, she said this with
an air as if the inference must
be drawn by even a stupid white man
306
"I know how to manage, dontdon't I?"
It was refreshing to get food which
could be eaten without producing
the effectunpleasant described by Revd
John Newton of St Mary's
Woolnoth -
London when obliged
to eat the same roots while
a slave in the West Indies
SThe day (Saturday 14th) for a wonder
45 was fair and the sun
shone so as to allow us to
dry our clothing and other
goods many of which
were mouldy and rotten
from the long continued
damp - The guns rusted
in spite of being oiled
every evening

During the night we
were all awakened by a
terrific shriek from one
of Manenko's ladies - She
piped out so loud and
long we all imagined she
had been seized by a lion
and my men all seiz snatched
up their arms which they
always place so as to
be ready at a moment's
notice and ran to the rescue
but we found the alarm
had been caused by one
of the oxen thrusting his
head into her hut and
smelling at her she had put
307
her hand on his cold wet nose
and thought it all over with
her -

On Sunday afternoon
messengers arrived from
Shinte expressionexpressing his approbation
46 of the objects we have in
view in our journey
through his country and
that he was glad of the
prospect of a way being
opened up which white
man might visit him
and allow him to purchase
ornaments at pleasure
Manenko now
threatened in
sport to go on
and I cwould now see that the
what seemed to me the
dilly dallying way of ^ this lady Manenko
was the proper mode
of making acquaintance
with the Balonda and
much of the favour with
which I was afterwards
recievedreceived in different places
was owing to my sending
forward messengers to
to state the object of coming
before entering the town
When we came in sight
of a village we sat down
under the shade of a tree
and sent forward a man
to give notice of who we
were and what were our
objects - The headman of
308
of the village then sent out
his principal men as shinteShinte
now did to bid us welcome
and shewsshows a tree under
which we might sleep -
47 Before I had profited by the
rather tedious teaching of
Manenko I sometimes entered
a village and created unintention-
-al alarm - The villagers
201 would continue to [look
upon [us with suspicion
as long [as we remained
Shinte sent us two large
baskets of manioc and
six dried fishes - ^ His men They had
on the skins of a monkey
called Poluma in their tongue
which is of a jet black
colour except the long mane
which is pure white - It is
said to be found in the
North - or country of Matiamvo
11 the paramount chief of all
the Balonda - We learned
from them that that they are
in the habit of praying
to their idols in when
unsuccessful in killing
game or in any other
enterprise - They behaved
with reverence at our
religious services - This
will appear important
309
if the reader remembers
the almost total want of
prayer and reverence we
encountered in the South -

48
Our friends informed
us that Shinte would be highly
honoured by the presence
of three white men in his
town at once - Two others
had sent forward notice
of their appraoch from
another quarter (the West)
Could this be Barth or Krapf
How pleasant to meet
with Europeans in such
an out of the way region
The rush of thoughts made
me almost forget my fever
"Are Have they theof the same colour
as I am - ?" -- "Yes exactly so"
"And Havehave they the same
hair?" -- "Is that hair? we
thought it was a wig - "? We
never saw the like before"
This white man must be of
the sort that lives outin the
sea" My men took the hint
from this and always
sounded my praises after-
wards as a true specimen
of the variety of white men
who live in the Sea - "Look
at his hair it is made quite
straight by the ^ sea water"

Robinson I explained to them again
& again that when it was
said we came out of the
49 sea it did not mean that
we came from beneath
the water - but the fiction
was too pleasant and I
believe when I was out
of hearing my men always
represented themselves
as led by a genuine
specimen of the he mermaids "Just see his
hair"!

As the strangers had wooly
hair like themselves I had
n to give up the idea of meeting
anything more European
than two cross breed Portuguese
engaged in trading for
slaves and other articles
ivory and beesbees' wax -

On theThe 16th weafter a short
march we came to a most
lovely valley about a mile
& a half ^ wide and stretching away
Eastwards ^ up to a ^ low prolongation of
Monakadzi - A small
stream meanders down the
socentre of this pleasant green
glen and on a little rill
which flows into it from
the Southern side Western side
stands the town of Kabompo
or as he likes best to be called
Shinté
311
When Manenko thought the sun
was high enough for us
50 to make a lucky entrance
we found the town embowered
in tropical trees having great
expansion
of leaf and bananas
The streets are straight - andd
present such a ^ complete contrast
to those of the Bechuanas which are
all very tortuous - Here
too we first saw native
huts with square walls
and round roofs - The
fences hedges or walls of the courts
which surround the huts
are wonderfully straight and
built made of straightupright poles
a few inches apart and ^ strong grass
or leafy bushes neatly woven
between - In the courts were
little plantations of tobacco
a little solanaceous plant
which the Balonda use
as a relish and sugar cane
and bananas - Many of
the poles have grown again
and trees of the Ficus indica
family have been planted
around in order to give
to the inhabitants a grateful
shade - They regard it with
with some sort of veneration
as a medicine or charm -
312
Goats were browsing about
and when we made our
51 appearance a crowd of negroes
all fully armed ran towards
as if they would eat us
up - Some had guns but
the manner in which
they were held shewedshowed that the
owners were more used
to bows and arrows than
than white man's weapons -
After surrounding and looking
staring at us for an hour
they began to disperse

The two African Portuguese
(crossbreeds) of whom we had
heard, had erected a little
encampment opposite ours
the place where ours was
about to be made - One
of them whose spine had been
injured in youth, a rare
sight in this country came
and visited us, and I
returned the visit next morning
His tall His companion a tall yellow
had that sickly hue yellow
hue which made him
look fairer than myself
but his head was covered
with a ^ crop mat of un-mistakeableunmistakable
wool - They had a gang
of young female slaves
in a chain hoeing the
313
ground in front of their
encampment to clear it
52 of weeds & grass - They seemed
to have were purchased
recently in Lobale whence they
the traders had now come - There
were many Mambari with
them and the establishment
was conducted with that
military order which pervades
all the arrangements of
the Portuguese colonists - A
drum was beat and trumpet
sounded at certain hours quite
in military fashion - It was
the first time most of my
men had seen menslaves in
chains - "They are not men ^ (meaning they
are beasts)
who treat their children so"

The Balonda are real
negroes having much more
wool on their heads and
bodies than any of the Bechuanas
or Caffre tribes - They are
generally very dark in colour
and from among them
have been drawn many of
the slaves whioch have
been exported to Brazil - But
while they have ga general
similarity to the typical negro
I amnever could nevfrom
my observation of them think
that we have ^ our ideal negro
seen in Tobacconiststobacconists' shops is the true type
314
A large proportion of the Balonda
have heads elongated somewhat
53 upwards backwards & upwards
thick lips - flat noses
elongated ossa calces &c &c - but
there are so many good
looking well shaped heads
and persons among them
that ^ hating except for the inclination
to thick lips I thought that
Ethnologists have gone
very much on the principle
of comparing the very
ugliest specimens of
of the black races with
the verythe most beautiful
specimens among ourselves

17th Tuesday We were honoured with
a grand reception by Shinte about
one oclocko'clock - Sambanza claimed the
honour of presenting meus Manenko
being ^ slightly indisposed - The Native Portuguese
and Mam[bariMambari went fully armed with
guns in order to give Shinte a a
203 parting salute - They had their drummer
and higher trumpeter making as
315
much noise as very old instruments would
yield - tThe kotla or place of
audience was about a hundred
54 yards square and two graceful
specimens of the ficus indica
stood near one end - Under one
of these sat Shinte on a sort of
throne covered with a leopard's
skin; He had on a checked jacket
and kilt of scarlet baize edged
with green. - Many strings of
large beads hung from his
neck and his limbs were
covered with iron & copper
armlets and bracelets - On his
head he wore a hellmet made of
beads woven neatly together &
crowned with a great bunch
of goose feathers - close to him
sat three lads
with great
sheaves of
arrows over
their shoulders As we entered
the kotla the party of Manenko clapped
their hands vigorously as a
salutation to Shinte

p.del:
Behind him sat eighty or one
hundred women

div.p:
When we entered the kotla wethe
whole party of Manenko saluted
Shinte him by clapping their hands &
Sambanza did obeisance by
rubbing his chest & arms
with ashes - - One of the trees
being unoccupied I retreated to it
for the sake of the shade and
my whole party did the same
we were now about forty yards
from the chief and gcould see
316
the whole ceremony - The different
sections of the tribe came
forward in the same way ^ that we
55 did the headman making obeizanceobeisance
with ashes which he carried
with him for the purpose - Then
came the soldiers all armed to the
teeth running and shouting
towards us - ^ with their swords drawn and their faces screwed
up so as to appear as savage
as possible for the purpose
I thought of trying whether they
could not make us take to
our heels - As we sdid not they
turned round towards Shinte
and saluted him then retired
When all had come and were
seated then began the curious
capering usually seen in peechos
A man starts up and imitates
the most approved d attitudes
observed in actual fight
sh Throwing the javelin - recievingreceiving
another in the shield, springing
to one side to avoid another
running backwards or forwards
Sp leaping &c - Here - the spokesman
of Nyamoana and Sambanza
stalked backwards & forwards
in front of Shinte and gave
forth in a loud voice all
they had been able to learn
either from ourselves or
people of our past history
317
and connection with the Makololo
the return of the captives - The wish
56 to open the country to trade - The
bibleBible as a word from heaven
the white mansman's desire to live in
for the tribes to live in peace -
ought to have taught the Makololo
that first for the Balonda never
attacked them yet they attacked
had assailed ^ the Balonda - perhaps he is
fibbing perhaps not - They rather
thought he was - But as the
Balonda had good hearts and
Shinte had never done any harm
to any one he had better recievereceive
the white man him well and send him on
his way. - Sambanza was
gaillygaily attired and abesides a
profusion of beads had a
cloth so long ^ that a boy carried it
after him as a train

Behind Shinte sat about
a hundred women clothed in
their best, which best happened
to be a profusion of red blaize
The chief wife of Shinte one of the
Matibele or
ZulausZulus sat
in front with a curious
red cap on
her head : S During the intervals
between the speeches these ladies
burst forth into a sort
of plaintive ditty but it was
impossible for any of us
to catch whether it was in
praise of the speaker, of Shinte
or of themselves - This was
318
the first time I had ever seen
women present in a public assembly
57 In the South the women arewere
not permitted to enter the Kotla
and when invited to come
to a religious service there
would not enter untilluntil
ordered to do so by the chief - but
here they expressed approbation
by clapping their hands and
laughing to different speakers
and Shinte frequently turned
round and spoke to them

A party of Musicians consisting of three drummers
and four
performers on the piano went
round the Kotla chiefseveral times
regaling us with their music
The drums are neatly carved
from the trunk of a tree &
have a small hole in the
side covered with a bit of
spidersspider's web - The Ends are
covered with the skin of an
antelope ^ pegged on and when they
wish to beat tighten it they
hold it to the fire to make
it contract - They instruments are beaten
with the hands

Morimba The piano named Marimba
consists of two bars of wood
placed side by
side (here quite straight but farther
North bent round so as to resemble
half the tire of a carriage wheel
319
across these are placed about
fifteen keys each of which is
58 two or three inches broad &
fourfifteen or eighteen inches long,
their thickness is regulated
according to the deepness of
the note required - Each of
the keys has a calabash
beneath it a part being cut
off the upper part of which
to enable it to embrace the
fobars and form ^ hollow sounding-
-boards hollows to the keys - They too
are of different sizes according
to the key, and the keys
are used little drumsticks
? elicit the notes - Rapidity of
execution seems much
admired among ^ them and the
music so is pleasant to
the ear - In Angola the
Portuguese use the Marimba
in their dances -

Cross When nine speakers
had concluded their speechesorations
Shinte stood up and so did
all the people - He had maintained
true African dignity of manner
all the while, but my people
remarked that he never took
his eyes off me for a moment
About a thousand people were
present according to my
calculation and about three
hundred soldiers - The sun had
320
now become hot and the scene
ended by the Mambari discharging
59 their guns.

18th On Wedends We were awakedawakened
during the night by a messenger
from Kabompo Shinte requesting
ata visit at a very unseasonable
hour - As I was just in
the sweating stage of an intermittent
and the path to the town lay
through a wet valley, I declined
going - Kolimbota who knows
their customs best urged
me to go but independantindependent
of sickness I hated words of the
night - my and deeds of
darkness - "I was neither
a hyaenahyena not a witch"
Kolimbota thought we ought to
conform to their wishes
in everything I thought we
ought to have some wishchoice
in the matter as well, which
put him into high dudgeon -
However at ten next
morning we went and
were led into the courts
of Shinte ^ the walls of
woven rods all very neat and
high - Many trees stood
within the inclosures and afforded
a grateful shade - These are
planted by man for we saw
some recently put in with
grass wound round the trunk
to protect them from the Sun -
321
The otherwise waste corners ^ of the streets were
planted with sugar cane and
60 bananas which spread their
large light leaves over the walls

The Ficus indica, tree under
which we sat, had very large
leaves but shewedshowed its relationship
to the Indian Banian by sending
down shoots towards the
ground - Shinte soon came
and appeared a man of
upwards of forty fifty ^ five years
of age of frank and open
countenance - Heand and about the
middle height - He seemed in
good ⎡humour and said he
Chester had expected yesterday that
a man who came from
the Ggods would have come
approached and talked to him
That had been my own
intention in going to the reception
but when we came & saw
the formidable preparations
and all his own men keeping
at least forty yards off from
him, I ^ yielded to the representations
solicitations of my men and
remained atunder by the tree - ^ opposite to that under
which he sat This
remark confirmed my previous
belief that a frank open
fearless manner is the most
winning with all these Africans
I stated the object of my
journey and mission
322
and to all I advanced the old gentleman
61 clapped his hands in approbation
He replied through a spokesman
then all the company joined
in the response by clapping of hands too

After the more serious
business was over I asked
if he had ever seen a white
man before - He replied "never
you are I was the very first heI hadve seen
with a white skin and straight
hair - your clothing too is
different from any we have
ever seen too" - They had been
visited by Native Portuguese
(crossbreeds) and Mambari
alonly - He presented

I haOn learning from some
of the people that "Shinte's
mouth was bitter for want
of tasting ox flesh" I presented
him with one of to his
great delight and as his
country is so well adapted
for them advised him to
begin a trade in cows
with the Makololo - He was
pleased with the idea and
when we returned ^ from LoandoLuanda
we found that he had
profited by the hint for he
had got three and one
of them justified my opinion
of the country for it was
more like a prize hieferheifer for
fatness then any we had
323
seen in Africa - He soon
afterwards sent us a basket
62 of green maize boiled - another
of manioc meal and a
small fowl - The maize
shewsshows by its size the fertility
of the black soil of all the
valleys here and so does
the manioc though no manure
is ever applied - We saw
Manioc attain a height of six
feet & upwards and this
is a plant which requires
the very best soil

During this time
Manenko had been very busy
with all her people in
getting up a very pretty hut
and court yard - to be as
she said her residence
always when white men
where were brought by
her along the same path
When she heard that we
had given an ox to her
uncle she came forward
to us with the
air of one
wronged and explained that "this
was her white man, she
had brought him here and
that therefore the ox was
hers not Shinte's - She took
She ordered her
men to
bring it she got it slaughtered by her
own people ^ by them and presented
her uncle with a leg only
324
This is mentioned exactly as it
happened and Shinte did not
63 seem at all annoyed by the
occurrence

19th I was awakedawakened ^ at an early ^ hour by
a messenger from Shinte
but I had just got the thirst
of a raging fever asuagedassuaged by
the bursting forth of a copious
perspiration ^ and declined
going for
a few hours - Violent action
of the heart all the way to
the town did not predispose
me to be patient with the
delay which occurred probably
on account of the divination
being unfavourable - "They
could not find Shinte" When
I returned to bed another message
was recievedreceived "Shinte wished
to say all he had to tell mesay at
once" - This was too tempting
an offer so hewe went & he
had a fowl ready ^ in his hand to present
a calabas a basket of manioc
meal and a calabash of
mead - Referring to the
constantly ^ every recurring attacks of
fever he remarked that
was the only thing which
would prevent my reaching
LoandoLuanda for he a successful
issue to my journey for
he had a guide men to give
me who knew all the paths
325
which led to the white men
He had himself travelled far
64 as a young man - On asking
what he would recommend
for the fever, "Drink plenty
of the mead and as it gets
in it will drive the fever
out" - It was rather strong, and
I suspect he likes the remedy
pretty well even though he has
no fever - He had always
been a friend to Sebituane
and now that his son ^ Sekeletu was
in his place he ^ Shinte was not
a friend but a Sekeletu's father
to him, and if a son asks a favour
the father must do it give
it - He was highly pleased
with the large calabashes of
clarified butter and fat
which Sekeletu had sent him
and wished to detain Kolimbota
that he might send a present
back to Sekeletu by his
hands - This proposition
we afterwards discovered
was Kolimbota's own as
he heard so much about
the ferocity of the tribes
inthrough which we were
to pass that he wished to
save his skin - As will
be seen further on he
was the only one of our
party to returned with a wound

326
Dennett We were particularly
struck in passing through
65 the village with the punti
punctiliousness of manners
shewnshown by the Balonda -
The inferiors on meeting
their superiors in the street
at once drop on their knees,
and rub dust on their arms
and chest:, cont They continue
the salutation ^ of clapping their hands untilluntil the
great ones have passed;
TSambanzaSambanza knelt down
in this manner till the
Son of Shinte had passed him

We several times saw
the woman, who occupies the
position of drawer of water
for Shinte -, she rings a
bell as she passes along
to give warning to all to
keep out of her way;
It would be a grave offence
for any one to come near
her, and exercise an evil
influence by his presence
ofn the drink of the chief
I suspect that offences
of the slightest character
among the poor are
made the pretext for
selling them tor their children
to the Mambari - for a
young man of Lobale had
327
fled into the country of Shinte
and located himself without
66 shewingshowing himself to the chief;
This was considered an
offence sufficient to warrant
his being seized and offered
for sale while we were
there; - WHe had not reported
himself so they did not know
the reason of his running
away from his own chief; - and that chief might
accuse himthem of recievingreceiving
a criminal - It was
curious to notice the effect
of the slave trade in blunting
the moral susceptibility:
No chief in the South would
treat a fugitive in this way -
mMy men were horrified at
the act even though old Shinte
and his counsel had some
shewshow of reason on their side And both the
Barotse & the
Makololo
declared that
if the Balonda
only knew
of the policy
pursued by
them to
fugitives but
few would
remain long
with their
present chief
Shinte - They
My men excited
the wonder of
this people by
stating that
every one of
them had a
cow at least in
his possession

Another incident which
occurred while we were here
many be mentioned as totally
unknown in the South
Two children, ^ of between 7 & 8 years, went out ^ to collect firewood a short
distance from their parents
home ^ which was a quarter of a mile from the village, and were kidnapped;
The distracted parents could not
find a trace of them - This
happened so close to the town,
where there are no beasts of prey,
that we I suspect some of the
high men of Shinte's court
67 328
must have been the guilty parties,
They can sell them by night The Mambari
erect large
huts of a
square
shape to stow
these stolen
ones in -
They are welled
fed, but
aired by
night only - ;
The frequent
p kidnapping
from outlying
hamlets
explains the
stocadesstockades
we saw
around them
The parents
have no
redress, for
even
and Shinte himself seems
fond of working in the dark
One night he sent for me,
though I always stated I liked
all my dealings to be above-
-board: When I went he
presented me with a slave
girl about ten years old - He
said he had always been
in the habit of presenting his
visitors with a child - On
my thanking him, and saying
that I thought it wrong
to take away children from their
parents, - that I wished him
to give up this system altogether,
and trade in cattle, ivory, and
beesbees' wax - , he urged that she
was to be a child to me bring
me water, and that a ^ great man
ought to have a child for the
purpose yet I had none - The
As I mentioned that I had four
children, and would be very
sorry if my chief would take
my little girl and give her
away, and that I would
prefer this child to remain
and comfo carry water for
her own mother; - he thought
I was dissatisfied with her
the size, and sent for one
329
68 a head taller - This, withAfter many
explanations of how we detest
slavery, and how displeasing
it must be to God to see his
children selling each other as
and giving each other, so much
grief as this child's mother
must feel, I declined her
also. - If but I could have taken
her with my family & instructed
for the purpose
of instruction, her for a time and then
returned her as a free woman,
according to a promise I should
have made to the parents,
I might have done so; - But
to take her away, and probably
never be able to secure her
return would have produced
no good effect on the
minds of the Balonda - They
would not as I taught
themn have seen evidence
of the existence of of our hatred to
slavery - And the kind attentions
of my friends, would, as it
almost always does in s
similar heacases, have turned
the poor thing's her head - The difference in
position between them and us
is as great as between the
the lowest and highest among
in England; ^ ourselves - and we know
the effects of sudden elevation
on wiser heads than hers, whose
owners have not been born to it -
69 330
Shinte was most anxious
to see the pictures of the Magick
Lantern; - But fever had
so such a weakening an effect
and there was such violent
action of the heart with
buzzing in the ears, I
could not go for several
days - wWhen I went I did
go for the purpose he
had his principal men,
and the same crowd
of court beauties around
near him as at the reception.
The first picture exhibited
was Abraham ^ knife in hand about to
slaughter Isaac his son
Isaac; - It was shewnshown
as large as life, and
the uplifted knife was
in the act of striking
the lad; - The ^ Balonda men
remarked it was much
likermore like a god than the
things of wood or
clay they worshipped -
I explained that this
was the first of a race
to whom God had given
the bibleBible we h now held,
and that among the his
children Our Saviour
appeared - The ladies
listened with awe; - When
70 331
I moved that slide the uplifted
dagger moved towards them,
& they thought - it was to
be sheathed in their bodies
instead of Isaac's. "Mother
Mother"! they all shouted
at once; and off they rushed
helter skelter, tumbling pell
mell over each other, and
the little idol huts and
tobacco bushes; - We could
not get ^ one of them back again
Shinte, however, sat bravely
through the whole, and examined
with interest the instrument
afterwards - An explanation
was always added after
each time of shewingshowing
its powers, so that no
one should imagine there
was aught supernatural
in it, and had Mr Murray
who kindly brought it
from England seen its
popularity among both
Makololo and Balonda
he would not have
regretted the direction his
generosity then took, - It was
the only mode of instruction
I was ever pressed to
repeat or that they
came long distances for
the express purpose of
both seeing & hearing

One cannot get away
quickly from these chiefs,
They like to have - the honour
of strangers residing in
their villages, - here we
had an additional cause
of delay in frequent
rains - Twenty four hours
never elapsed without
heavy showers; - Everything
is affected by the
dampness, - Surgical instruments
become all rusty, - clothing
mildewed and shoes shoes
mouldy - My little tent
was now so rotten
and full of small holes
that every heavy shower
caused a fine mist
to des-cenddescend on my blankedblanket
and make me fain
to cover methe head with
it - Heavy dews lay on
everything in the morning
even inside the tent,
And there is only a short
time of sunshine in the
afternoon so interrupted
by thunder showers that
we cannot dry our
bedding

p.seg:
The winds coming
from the North balways
bring heavy clouds & rain

In the South the only heavy rains
noticed are those which
come from the North East,
or East, - The thermometer
falls as low as 72˚ when
there is ^ no sunshine, though ^ when it is fair
generally as high as 82˚
(the thermometer (protected) throughout the
even in the mornings & evenings

div.p:
24th We expected to have started
today but Sambanza, who
had been sent off early
in the morning for guides,
returned at midday
without them and drunk,
This was the first case of
real babbling intoxication
we had seen in the country
The Boyaloa, of the or beer,
of the country possesses
more of a stupifyingstupefying
than exciting power, hence
the beer bibersbibbers are often
great sleepers-; They may
frequently ^ be seen sleeping lying on
their faces sound asleep; This
peculiarity ^ of posture was ascribed by
no less an authority than
Aristotle to wine, - while those
who were sent asleep by beer
were believed "to lie upon
their backs"

XXX 334
Kerr Sambanza however had got
into a state of inebriation
from indulging in mead
similar to that which
Shinte presented ^ to us which is and much
more powerful than boyaloa
As far as we could collect
from his incoherent sentences
1 Shinte had said the rain was
too heavy for our departure
and the guides still required
time for preparation - He
himself was busy getting some
meal ready for my use
in the journey - As it rained
nearly all day it was
no sacrifice to submit to
his advice and
remain remain - Sambanza staggered
to Manenko's hut, she
however who had never
promised "to ^ love honour and
obey him", had not been
"nursing her wrath to keep it warm"
had not like a much
better woman in Scotland
been - "nursing her wrath to keep it warm"
so she bundled him cooly
into the hut & put him to
bed -

Kerr As the last proof of
friendship Shinte came into
my tent though it could
scarcely contain more
than one - looked at all
the curiosities - The quicksilver
335
the looking glass - books - hair
brushes & comb - watch &c &c
with the greatest interest
then closed the tent so that
no one ^ of his own people might see the
extravagance of which
he was about to be guilty -
He Then drew out ^ from his
clothing a string
of beads and the end of
a coneical shell which
is considered in parts
far from the sea of
2 as great value as the
Lord MayorsLord Mayor's badge - is in
London - He hung it
round my neck and
said "there now you
have a proof of my
friendship" - My men
informed me that ^ two
of these ^ such shells are so highly
valued in this quarter
that as evidences of
distinction, that for two
of them a slave might
be bought - & five would
be considered a handsome
price for an elephant's
tusk worth ten Pounds -
At our last interview old
Shinte pointed out our
Intemesi principal guide N Intemesi
a man about fifty
who was he said ordered
336
to remain by us till we
should reach the sea - that
I had now left Sekeletu far
behind and must henceforth
look to ^ Shinte him alone for aid
and that would always be
most ^ cheerfully rendered - This
was only his polite way
of expressing his wishes
for my success - It was
only the good words only of
3 the guides which were to
aid me from the next
chief (Katema's) on to the sea
There they were to turn but
he gave a good supply
of food for the journey
in front and after
mentioning as a reason
for letting us go even now
that as we had been
several days with him
no one could say we
had been driven away
from the town - he
gave a most hearty
salutation and we parted -
with the wish that God
might bless him -

337
26th Leaving Shinte's with
eight ^ six of the his men to aid
in carrying our luggage
we passed down the lovely
valley in which the town
stands in a wNortherly direction
then ^ passed a little to the West through
pretty open forest - and
slept at the ^ a village of a
Balonda headman named Capende
In the morning we had
a pretty fine range of green
hills called Saloisho on
and were informed that
4 they were well inhabited
by the people of Shinte
who worked in iron
the one of which abounds
in their hills

Mead The country through
which we passed possessed
the same general character
of flatness and forest that
we noticed before - The
soil ˅ is is dark with a tinge
of red - TheIn some places
it might be called red
and all seemed appeared very
fertile - Every valley
contained villages of
twenty or thirty huts
and gardens of manioc
which here is looked
upon as the staff of life
338
Very little labour is required for
its cultivation - The earth is
drawn up into oblong beds
about three feet broad
and one in height and
into them are planted pieces
of the Manioc stalk - at four
feet apart - a crop of
beans or earth nuts is are
planted between and when
these are reaped the
ground around the manioc
cleared is cleanred of weeds - In
from ten to eighteen months
after planting according
to the quality of the soil
5 the roots are fit for food
There is no necessity for
reaping soon, as it ^ the roots only
becomes become bitter &
dry at the end of three years
When a woman takes
up ^ the roots she thrusts in
a piece or two
of the upper a piece of a stalks into
the hole and a new
crop is thereby begun - The
plant grows to a height of
six feet and every part
of the plant is useful - The
leaves may be cooked
as vegetable - The roots are
abofrom three to four
inches in diameter and
from twelve to eighteen
inches long

339
There are two varieties of the
Manioc or Cassava - one sweet
and wholesome the another
bitter and actually containing
a poison but much
more speedy in its growth
then the ^ first other - This last
property makes causes
its perpetuation - When
we reached the village of
Capende on the banks of
the rivulet Lonatje we
were presented with so much
of the poisonous kind we
were obliged to leave it
6 To get rid of the poison
the people place it for
four days in a pool of
water - It then has
becomes partially decomposed
and is taken out stripped
of its skin and exposed
to the sun to be dried
When dried it is easily
pounded into fine white
meal closely resembling
starch which has either
a little of the peculiar,
taste, arising from
decomposition, or no
more flavour than starch
When intended to be used
as food this meal is
stirred into boiling water
340
They put as much in as
can be moistened - One
man holding the pot vessel and
the other stirring the porridge
with all his might - This
is the common mess
of the country - Though
hungry we could just but
manage to swallow it with
the aid of a little honey
which I shared with
7 my men as long as it
lasted - It is very unsavoury
(Scottice Wersh) and no
matter how much one
may ˅ stow away ingesteat, in two hours
afterwards ^ he is as hungry as ever
When less meal is employed
it is exactly like a basin
of starch in the hands
of the laundress, and to
the curious if the starch
were made from diseased
potatoes some idea might
be formed of the Balonda
potage which hunger alone
forced us to eat - Santuru
forbade his nobles to eat
it as it caused coughing
and expectoration

Our chief guide
Ntemesa sent orders to
all the villages around
341
on our route that ShintesShinte's friends
must have abundance of
provisions - Our progress
was impeded by the time
requisite for communi-
-cating the chiefschief's desire
and the preparation of
meal - We recievedreceived
far more food from
Shinte's people than
from himself - Kapende
for instance presented
two large baskets of meal
8 Three of Manioc roots steeped
and dried in the sun &
ready to be converted into
flour - three fowls and seven
eggs - with three smoke
dried fishes and others
gave with similar
liberality - I retugave to these
headmen small bunches
of my stock of beads &
the apology that we were
now on our way
to the market for these
goods - It was always
politely recievedreceived

We had an opportunity
of observing in our guides
much more punctilious-
ness in their manners
than in any of the tribes
342
farther south - They gave us
food but would not
partake of it in our
presence - when we had
cooked it - Nor would
they eat their own food
in our presence - When
it was cooked they retired
into a thicket and eatate
their potage then all stood
up and clapped their
hands and praised
Ntemesa for it - The
Makololo who are
9 accustomed to the most
free and easy manners
inheld out handfuls
of what they had cooked
to any of the Balonda
near but it was they
refused to taste - They
are very punctilious in
their manners to each
other - Each hut has its
own fire and when it
goes out they make it
afresh for themselves
rather than take it from
a neighbour - I believe
much of this arises from
superstitious fears - In
the deep dark forests
near each village as
already mentioned you see
343
the idols intended to represent
the human heads or lion
(alligator) or crooked stick
smeared with medicine,
or simply a small pot
of medicine in a little shed or miniature huts
with a little
mounds of earth
in them
with the
beards
But in the darker recesses
we meet with human
faces cut in the bark
of trees the outline of
which ^ closely resemble
those seen on Egyptian
monuments - Frequent
cuts are made on the
trees all along the paths
and votive offerings
are placed on branches
10 These consist of small
pieces of manioc roots
or cobs of maize - There
are also to be seen
every few miles heaps
of sticks which are
treated in cairn fashion
by every one throwing
throwing a small
branch to the heap in
passing - - or a few
sticks are placed on
the path and each
passer by turns from
his course and forms
a sudden bend to one
side in the road to one side -
344
It seems as if their minds
were in doubt & dread in
these secret recesses of
the forest and that they
were striving to propitiate
some superior being residing
their by their offerings

Berry The dress of the Balonda
men consists of athe skins
of some small animal
as the jackalljackal or wild
cat softened and hung before
and behind from a
11 girdle round the loins
The dress or undress of
the rather of the ladies is
of a nondescript character
but they were not
immodest - They stood before
us as perfectly unconscious
of indecency ^ of any indecorum in undress as we could
be with our clothes on -
But while ignorant of
their own deficiency they
could not maintain their
gravity at the sight of my
the nudity of my
men posteriorly - Much
to the annoyance of my
companions the young
girls laughed outright when
ever their backs were turned
to them

345
After crossing the Lonatje
we came to some pretty
villages embowered as
the negro villages usually
are in bananas - shrubs
and Manioc - and near
the banks of the Leeba
We haformed our encampment
in a nest of serpents
one of which bit one of
which one of our men
but the wound was harmless
The people of the surrounding
villages presented us
with large quantities
of food in obedience
to the mandate of Shinte
12 without expecting any
equivalent - One village
had lately come hither
from the country of
Matiamvo - They of
course continue to
acknowledge him as
paramount chief but
the frequent instances
which occur of people
changing from one
part of country to
another shewshow that the
great chiefs possess
only a limited power
The only peculiarity we
observed in these people
346
the habit of plaiting the
beard into a three fold cord.

Cazembe As ^ the Balonda chief Cazembe was pointed
out to us by Sambanza as
to the ^ N- E-North East and by E-East from
the town of Shinte, and
Sambanza and others
had and great
numbers of
people in
this quarter
have gone thither for the
purpose of purchasing
copper leglets made in
Cazembe's town, and
reportedreport the distance to be
about five days' journey,
I made enquiries of
some of the oldest
inhabitants of the villages
at which we were staying
13 respecting the visit of
Pereira and Lacerda to
that town - An old grey
headed man replied that
they had often heard of
white men before but
never had seen one
and that one came to
Cazembe when our
informant was young
& returned again without coming near
this part of the country
The people of Cazembe are
Balŏnda or Balŏi
and his country has
been termed Lŏnda - Lunda
or Lui by the Portuguese

It was always difficult
to get our guides to move
away from a place - They
wWith the authority of
the chief ^ they felt as comfortable
as kings-messengersking's-messengers ^ can be could be
could be
can be when
living at the
public expense can make themselves
and were indisposed
to forgego the pleasure of
living at free quarters -
My Makololo friends
were but ill prepared
drilled as yet and as
since they had never left their
own country before
except for purposes
of plunder they did not
14 take readily to the peaceful
system we now meant
to follow - They either
spoke too imperiously to
strangers or when reproved
for that were disposed
to follow the dictation
of everyone we met - When
Ntemesa our guide refused
to stir towards cross the
Leeba from
on the 31st January they would make
no effort to induce him
to go but I ^ having ordered them
to get ready and when
Ntemesa saw the
preparation he soon followed
our example and It
took us about four
hours to cross the Leeba
348
which is considerably smaller
here than where we left it -
Indeed only about a hundred
yards wide - It has the
same dark mossy hue - The
villagers lent us canoes
to effect our passage - And
having gone to a village
about three two miles from
the river I had the satisfation
of getting observations for
both longitude and Latitude
For the former the distance
15 between JSaturn and the Moon
and for the latter a meridian
altitude of canopus
Long-Longitude 22° 57' E-East Lat-Latitude 12° 6' 6" South

Wheeler These were the only opportunities
I had of ascertaining my
whereabouts in Londa
Again and again did I take
out mthe instruments and
just as all was right the
stars would be suddenly
obscured by clouds - I had
never observed so great
an amount of cloudiness
in any part of the South
country and as for the
rains I believe that
years at Kolobeng would
not have made my
little tent so rotten & thin
as one month had done
349
in Londa - I never observed
in the South ^ the heavy night
rains we had in this country
They often continued all night,
or then became heavier
about an hour before
dawn - Or if fair during
the night, at that day drew
nigh an extremely heavy
still pouring rain fset in
16 without wandrning - Five
out of every six days had
this pouring rain, at at
or near break of day for months
together and they soon
beat my tent so thin -
that a mist fell through on
my face & which made everything damp,
The rains It wasere occasionally but
not always accompanied
with very loud thunder.
Next morning we had a
fine view of two hills
called piriPiri (Peeri) meaning
Two on the side of the
river we had left - The
country there is named
Mokwankwa - And there Ntemese
informed us one of Shinte's
children was born when
he was in his progress
southwards from the country
of Matiamvo - This part
of the country would thus
seem to have been but
350
inhabited by the people of
Shinte. - He told me himself
that he had come into his
present country by command
of Matiamvo

Here we were surprised
to hear English cotton cloth
much more eagerly
enquired after than beads
and ornaments - They are
more in need of clothing
than the Bechuana
17 tribes living adjacent to
the Kalahari desert, who
have plenty of skins
for the purpose - Here
animals of all kinds
are rare, and a very
small piece of calico
is of great value

1st Feb-February Ntemese sent in
the midst of the heavy
rains which continued
all morning to say he
was laid up with
pains in his the stomach,
and must not be disturbed,
but when it cleared up,
about eleven, I saw our
friend walking off to
the village and talking
with a very loud voice.
On reproaching him for
351
telling an untruth, he turned it
off with a laugh by saying
he really had a complaint
in his stomach, which
I might cure by slaughtering
one of the oxen and
allowing him to eat beef.
He was evidently revelling
in the abundance of good
food, the chief's orders
brought us - and he did
not feel the shame I did,
18 when I gave a few
beads only in return
for large baskets of meal

A very old man visited
us where with a present
of maize, - he like the
others had never before
seen a white man. - And
when conversing with
him, some of the young
men remarked that they
were the true ancients,
for they had now seen
more wonderful things
than their forefathers

One of Ntemese's
men stole a fowl given
me by the lady of the village.
When charged with the
theft - , Everyoneeveryone of his
Ntemese's party vociferated their his
352
innocence and indignation
at being suspected - Continuing
their loud asseverations
and gesticulations for some
minutes, one of my men
Loyanka went off to the
village, brought the lady
who had presented the
fowl as able to identify it -
Then pointed to the hut
in which it was hidden.
The Balonda collected
19 round him evincing
great wrath, but he
Loyanka seized his battle
axe in the proper manner
for striking, - and placing
himself on a little hillock
soon made them moderate
their tones. - Ntemese then
called on me to send one
of my people to search
the huts if I suspected
his people - The man
sent soon found it, and
brought it out to the
confusion of Ntemese
and laughter of our
party - This incident
is mentioned to shewshow
that their much greater
superstition which
exists here, does not lead
to the practice of the virtues
353
We never met an instance
like this of theft from
a white man among the Makololo,
though they complain
of the Makalaka as addicted
to pilfering. - The honesty
of the Bakwains has been
already noticed. - Probably
the estimation in which
I was held as a public
benefactor, and in which
20 I was not yet known
to the Balonda, may account
for the sacredness with
with which my property was
treated. But other incidents
which happened subsequently
shewedshowed as well as this,
that thidolators are not
so virtuous as those who
have no idols -

Ker As the people on the banks
of the Leeba were the
last of Shinte's peopletribe
over which Ntemese had
power he was naturally
anxious to remain as
long as possible - He
was not idle but
made a peslarge wooden
pestle & mortar for his
wife during our journey
He also carved many
wooden spoons - and
a bowl - then commenced a basket
354
but as what he considered
good living was anything
but agreableagreeable to us who
had been accustomed to
milk and maize we
went on ^ forward on the 2d without
him - He soon followed
but left our pontoon
saying it would be
brought by the headman
of the village - This was
a great loss as we
afterwards found - but
it remained at this village
21 for two years and
when we returned a
mouse had eaten a
hole in it

We entered on an
extensive plains beyond
the Leeba at least twenty
miles broad and covered
with water ankle deep
in the shallowest parts
We deviated somewhat
from our N- W-North West course
by the direction of Ntemese
and keepkept the hills Peeri
nearly on our right
during a great part
of the first day - in order
to avoid the still more
deeply flooded plains
of Lobale (Luval?) on
ourthe West - These according
355
to Ntemese are at present
impassable being thigh deep
The plains are so perfectly
level that rain water
which this was ^ stands upon them for
months together - They
were not flooded by
the Leeba for that was
still far within its
banks - Here and there
as if dotted over the
22 surface are little islands
on which grow stunted
date bushes and scraggy
trees - The plains themselves
are covered with a pretty thick
sward of grass
andwhich conceals the
water and make the
flats appear as great
pale yellow coloured ^ prairies lands with
a clear horizon except
whenre interrupted here
and there by trees,
The clear rain ^ The water must have
stood some time for
on among the grass ^ for great
numbers of lotus flowers
were seen in full
blow - And the runs of
of water tortoises & crabs were observed - and otters also
which prey on
the fish that
find their way to it -

The continual
splashing of the feet of
the oxen keep the feet
of the rider constantly wet

356
and my men complain
of the perpetual wetness
of the paths by which
we have travelled in
Londa as softening their
horny soles - The only
information we can
glean is from Ntemesi
who points out the
different localities as
we pass along and among
23 the rest to "Mokala /a
a Mama" his "mama's ^ home" - " house
It was interesting to hear
this tall grey headed man
recalrecall the memories of
boyhood - All the Makalaka
children follow ^ cleave to the mother in in
cases of separation or
removal from one
part of the country to
another - This love
for mothers
does not argue
superior morality
in other respects
or else Ntemese
any injunctions
his Mama may
have given not
to tell lies - The
respect however
with which he
spoke of her
was quite characteristic
of his race The Bechuanas
on the contrary follow
the father care nothing
for their mothers
but cling to their fathers
especially if they have
any expectations of
becoming heirs to his
cattle - Our Bakwain
guide to the Lake, Rachosi,
told me that his mother
lived in the country of
Sebituane but though
357
a good specimen of the
Bechuanas he laughed
at the idea of going so
far as from the Lake
Ngami to the Chobe
merely for the purpose
of seeing her - Had
he been one of the
Makalaka he never
would have parted
from her

We made our
beds on one of the islands
and were but wretchedly
supplied with firewood
24 The booths constructed
by the men were but
sorry shelter for the
rain poured down without
intermission till midday
There is no drainage for
these prodigious masses
of water on these plains
except slow percolation
into the different
feeders of the Leeba and
into that river itself
The quantity of vegetation
has prevented the
country becoming furrowed
by many rivulets or
"nullahs" Were the country
not so remarkably flat the drainage
must have been effected by torrents even
in spite of the matted vegetation

XXXI 358
Mead The reason why these extensive
treesp plains are covered
with grasses only and
the little islands with
but scraggy trees may
be accounted for by
the fact observable every-
where in this country
that where water stands
for any length of time
in this country trees
cannot live - The
want of speedy drainage
destroys them and injures
it influences the growth
25 of those that are planted
on the islands for they
have no depth of earth
except not subjected to
the souring influence
of the stagnant water
The plains of Lobale
to the West of these are
said to be much more
extensive than any we
saw, and their vegetation
possesses similar peculiarities
When the stagnant
rain water had all soaked
in as must happen
during the months in
which there is no rain
travellers are put to shiftsstraits
for want of water - This
359
which is given on native
testimony for ^ but I can very
well believe that level
plains in which neither
wells nor gullies are
met with may after
the dry season present the
opposite extreme to what we
witnessed - Water could
however always be got by
digging; as a proof of
which we had on our
return when brought to
a stand on this very
plain by ^ severe fever; about fifteen
twelve miles from the Leeba
my men dug down a
few feet and found
26 an abundant supply
And we saw on one of the
islands the garden of a
man who in the dry season
had drankdrunk water from
a well in like manner
Plains like these cannot
be inhabited while the
present system of cultivation
lasts - The population at
present is not so very large
as to need them - They find
garden ground enough won
the gentle slopes at nethe
sides of the rivulets and
possess no cattle to eat off
the millions of acres of
360
fine hay we were now
wading through Any one
who has visited the Cape
Colony will understand me
when I say these immense
crops of grass have very
little resemble sown grasses
more than the tufty vegetation
of the South

I would here request
the particular attention of
the reader to the phenomenona
these periodically deluged plains
present because they have
a most important bearing
on the physical geography
27 of a very large portion of
this country - The Plains
of Lobale to the wWest of this
give rise to a great
many streams which Uunite
and form the deep never
failing Chobe - Similar
extensive flats give birth
to the Loeti and Kasai and
